awd_titl_txt: RUI: Isotopically Different Tunneling-Ready-State Structures in Hydride Transfer Reactions in Solution
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project, funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics & Mechanisms B Program of the Chemistry Division, Professors Yun Lu, James E. Eilers, and Kevin R. Tucker of the Department of Chemistry at Southern Illinois University Edwardsville are investigating how reactions in the human body work. Hydrogen transfer reactions are common in chemistry and biology.  About 50% of the biological reactions in the body involve hydrogen transfer.  This project may help scientists understand these biological processes.  The project involves expertise in three different areas of chemistry (organic, analytical and computational). The chemistry department at Southern Illinois University Edwardsville (SIUE) holds workshops that target high school teachers in the St. Louis Metro-East area, which has a large African-American population living below the poverty line. This program provides an opportunity for the research teams to involve the high school teachers and their students in the project, preparing them for college and a STEM career.  

The project investigates a new concept in the contemporary models for hydrogen (H)-wave transfer, i.e., H-tunneling. The new concept is that H-tunneling and its heavier isotope (deuterium (D) or tritium (T))-tunneling have different donor-acceptor distance (DAD) at the tunneling-ready-state (TRS) structures due to different masses thus different wave properties. Since a heavier isotope possesses shorter wavelength, its transfer requires a shorter donor-acceptor distance (DAD). The confirmation of the concept could change the traditional views about the H-transfer chemistry and the theory of the kinetic isotope effects (KIE).  The investigators use physical organic mechanistic analysis methods to distinguish the isotopically different TRS structures for various hydride- vs. deuteride-transfer reactions in solution.  They plan to study the primary isotope dependence of the secondary KIEs to distinguish the isotopically different TRS conformations.  They also investigate the primary isotope dependence of Hammett correlations to differentiate the isotopically different TRS electronic structures.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: BOARD OF TRUSTEES OF SOUTHERN ILLINOIS UNIVERSITY

por.por_cntn:
Key Outcomes:

  • Two systems show primary isotope dependence of Hammett correlations, supporting the isotopically different tunneling-ready state (TRS) electronic structures. Two other systems, however, do not show the dependence. The latter results do not necessarily disprove the isotopic TRS difference hypothesis.
  • Method to determine the competitive secondary kinetic isotope effects (KIEs) were developed using the MS and NMR techniques. Contamination of the signals for kinetic measurements hinders accurate determination of the KIE values for some systems. Conventional non-competitive back-to-back KIE measurement can still be an effective method to determine the small secondary KIEs.
  • The CH/CD and remote N- CH/CD secondary KIEs in some systems are not very sensitive to the primary isotope. This may be due to the fact that there is little steric/electronic effect on the CH/CD vibrations so that the expected results are not shown.
  • Temperature dependences of primary KIEs were determined for several hydride transfer reactions in various solvents. It was found that the more rigid the system the smaller the temperature dependence of KIEs. This supports the isotopic donor-acceptor distance (DAD) difference concept.
  • Two methods to compute the TRS structures were developed. Secondary KIEs were calculated and fit to the observed ones to give rise to the TRS structures and DADs. Results have been used to support the isotopically different TRS/DAD concept.

 

Intellectual Merits: This is a new physical-organic-chemistry research direction that studies the isotopologue – DAD – TRS structure relationship for H-tunneling reactions. Our results, together with those from the recent enzyme studies, challenge the traditional views about H-transfer chemistry and primary KIE theory. They also provide insight into the current explanation of “abnormal” KIEs in enzymes.

      The primary isotope effects on Hammett correlations are indeed equivalent to the substituent effects on primary KIEs. Study of the latter has been carried out in the past to explore the structure – KIE relationship. They were explained using the Melander–Westheimer principle together with the Hammond’s postulate on the basis of the semi-classical TS theory. Although a few researchers realized that the latter theories could not explain the reactions that contain a H-tunneling component, and some had attempted to use the Bell tunneling model to interpret the results, as of today, the origin of structure – KIE relationship for H-tunneling reactions is still elusive. Our research showed that the origin could be from the isotopically different electronic TRS structures due to the isotopic DAD difference. Note that this explanation is in violation of the Born-Oppenheimer approximation in which the H-transfer and D-transfer are assumed to use the same electronic potential energy surface and on which the traditional KIE definition is based.

      Conventional non-competitive back-to-back measurements of isotopic rates could still be an effective method to determine secondary KIEs, if great care is taken during the measurements and instrument could provide stable physical conditions such as light source and temperature. Some of the systems we studied show very small primary isotope effect on secondary KIEs. On the other hand, for the first time, the N-CH/D secondary KIEs for hydride (H) transfer reactions were determined. We used them to study the electronic structure of the TRS’s and attempt to differentiate the TRS electronic structures for H vs. D transfer reactions. We proposed that this type of secondary KIEs could be used for study of the TS/TRS structures for any relevant organic reactions.

      We studied the primary isotope effect on activation energies (Ea’s) for some systems. We found that the more rigid the two reaction centers the smaller the effect, i.e., the smaller the isotopically different activation energies (∆Ea = EaD - EaH). These results support the “isotopic TRS/DAD difference” concept. Furthermore, these results replicate the observations in enzymes and appeared to support the recently proposed role of protein motions in enzyme catalysis.

 

Broader Impacts: Results derived from the project have been disseminated to a broader audience through many pathways. These include 6 publications in various chemistry journals, several presentations to local and national chemistry conferences, special topic lectures to students, as well as more locally in the annual Probst lecture series of our school. Presently, more manuscripts are in preparation. Additionally, part of the research ideas developed has been included in a recent project supported by NIH. On the other hand, with the help of this award, the PI has trained 4 undergraduate students (2 female and 1 Africa-American) and 10 MS graduate students (5 female, 5 international, 6 already graduated). The research experience inspired students’ interests in sciences and many of them have gone to pursue Ph.D. degrees or work in the local chemical companies as problem solvers. Students are included as coauthors in all of our publications. Furthermore, supported by the grant, we purchased a double-mixing stopped-flow kinetic measurement instrument. Other faculty in the Department have started or planned to use it for collaborative research purposes.


Last Modified: 11/26/2022
Modified by: Yun Lu
por.por_txt_cntn:
Key Outcomes: 

Two systems show primary isotope dependence of Hammett correlations, supporting the isotopically different tunneling-ready state (TRS) electronic structures. Two other systems, however, do not show the dependence. The latter results do not necessarily disprove the isotopic TRS difference hypothesis.
Method to determine the competitive secondary kinetic isotope effects (KIEs) were developed using the MS and NMR techniques. Contamination of the signals for kinetic measurements hinders accurate determination of the KIE values for some systems. Conventional non-competitive back-to-back KIE measurement can still be an effective method to determine the small secondary KIEs.
The CH/CD and remote N- CH/CD secondary KIEs in some systems are not very sensitive to the primary isotope. This may be due to the fact that there is little steric/electronic effect on the CH/CD vibrations so that the expected results are not shown.
Temperature dependences of primary KIEs were determined for several hydride transfer reactions in various solvents. It was found that the more rigid the system the smaller the temperature dependence of KIEs. This supports the isotopic donor-acceptor distance (DAD) difference concept.
Two methods to compute the TRS structures were developed. Secondary KIEs were calculated and fit to the observed ones to give rise to the TRS structures and DADs. Results have been used to support the isotopically different TRS/DAD concept.
